docs.lead_paragraph: In a dark, musty garage in the Long Island city of Glen Cove, a child sleeps under rags and old clothes. Rain drips down into an electric light socket. The ceiling is caving in. The five people who live there bathe from buckets and pay $1,000 a month in rent. ''What can I do?'' says Rosa Benitez, the child's mother, a 31-year-old immigrant from El Salvador. ''I ask the landlord to fix it. He says if I complain I will be on the street.'' In Farmingville, Guadeloupe Crespo Alvarez, a middle-aged Mexican, lingers in bed. The tip of his foot, crushed by a truck a few weeks ago while he was hauling bricks on a day job, looks like a tree root, swelling black and blue out of a plaster cast. The boss sent him home with a pill, but no pay, he says, and the hospital refuses to operate to repair his bones because he has no insurance. Now he cannot make the $200 rent that he pays for his bunk in a ranch house crammed with 16 strangers.

headline.main: SLUMS BEHIND SHUTTERS: A special report.; Wages and Squalor for Immigrant Workers

docs.abstract: Tens of thousands of legal and illegal immigrants from Central America and Mexico live jammed into subdivided houses and partitioned apartments across Long Island, biding their time in invisible suburban slums that local officials say they have little hope of controlling; these men and women perform some of lowest jobs on Island's booming economic ladder, but earn wages far greater than anything they could have earned at home--up to $10 an hour; many of these jobs would not get done without immigrant labor; same booming economy that has drawn so many immigrants to Long Island has also created extraordinary shortage of affordable housing and enabled some landlords to charge thousands of dollars a month to groups of men who then split rent as many as 10 or 20 ways; photos (L)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: The Healtheon Corporation, a rapidly growing Silicon Valley start-up with big ideas for changing the health care system, said yesterday that it would buy WebMD Inc., a seven-month-old Internet company, in a stock deal valued at $7.85 billion. Healtheon is also allying itself with some of technology's best-known names, selling $250 million of its high-flying stock to the Microsoft Corporation and $110 million to other backers including the Intel Corporation and Excite Inc., the Internet portal company.

headline.main: Medical Records Company Announces Spree of Deals

docs.abstract: Healtheon Corp to buy WebMD Inc in stock deal valued at $7.85 billion; Healtheon is also selling $250 million of its stock to Microsoft Corp and $110 million to other backers, including Intel Corp and Excite Inc; Microsoft, which will have stake of more than 10 percent in combined company, Healtheon/WebMD, also pledges $100 million in advertising, which would be added to $40 million already committed for advertising by DuPont Co; Healtheon offers electronic processing of health care claims, and on-line registration for health plans; it also links doctors over Internet with hospitals, pharmacies, laboratories and insurance companies; WebMD specializes in Internet support groups in which consumers can learn about health care subjects (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE philosophers in the New York State Legislature are grappling with a subtle question: Is it right and just for a rental-car company to hustle you out of $9 a day? After contemplating ethical issues and depositing campaign contributions from the companies, the legislators appear ready to answer yes. They're poised to overturn New York's unusual law exempting renters from liability for damage to cars. A bill now in the Senate would restore renters' liability and allow companies to charge $9 a day for insurance against damage to the vehicle.

headline.main: The Big City; Car Renters Face Hot Seat On Insurance

docs.lead_paragraph: As Republican national chairman, Haley Barbour designed his party's campaign to cut the growth of Medicare. Now he has taken on a new assignment. As a lobbyist for a dozen large nursing home companies, he pleads with Congress for relief from the law he helped write. In 1995-96, Mr. Barbour told anyone who would listen that the explosive growth of Medicare threatened to bankrupt the program. He worked hand in glove with Speaker Newt Gingrich on legislation to rein in Medicare spending. Now he complains that Medicare is spending too little.

headline.main: Insider Bemoans What He Wished For

docs.abstract: Haley Barbour, former Republican national chairman, who worked with former House Speaker Newt Gingrich in 1995-96 in designing party's campaign to cut growth of Medicare, has become lobbyist for a dozen large nursing home companies and is pleading with Congress for relief from law he helped to write; now says underspending by Medicare for skilled nursing homes is having adverse effects on senior citizens; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks rose on optimism that the Federal Reserve's resolve to fight inflation will accelerate gains in the market. ''The Fed's willingness to act pre-emptively and address these issues is a major positive'' for stocks, said John Bartlett, a senior portfolio manager for Commerce Funds, a unit of Commerce Bancshares Inc. in St. Louis. ''Low and stable inflation and interest rates create the optimal environment for corporations' economic activity.''

headline.main: Central Bank Resolve to Fight Inflation Helps Send Dow Up

docs.abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 50.44 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 10,887.39; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 10.91 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,344.23; Nasdaq composite index climbs 19.04 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,577.40; graph; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first sign that the cost of health care insurance could rise 9 to 11 percent again next year, the nation's second-biggest buyer of health benefits said yesterday that it had agreed to an average increase of 9.7 percent in premiums for California's state and local government workers. The California Public Employees Retirement System, which negotiates coverage for a million people, said Kaiser Permanente, the financially troubled health maintenance organization that covers some 400,000 people in the system, would get the largest increase, an average 11.7 percent. That is on top of 10.75 percent for 1999 for Kaiser, which has been losing about $1 billion a year.

headline.main: Calpers Allows Increases in Health Premiums

docs.abstract: California Public Employees Retirement System agrees to average increase of 9.7 percent in premiums for California's state and local government workers; Kaiser Permanente will get largest increase, 11.7 percent; that is on top of 10.75 percent for 1999 for Kaiser; move is first sign that cost of health care insurance could rise 9 to 11 percent again next year (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Fed Leaves Rates Alone But Hints at Increase Later The Federal Reserve left interest rates steady but put investors and consumers on notice that it might raise them in coming months if it continued to see signs of increasing inflation. The shift in stance by the central bank's policy-making committee -- from neutral to leaning toward higher rates -- was subtle but signaled a clear change in the Fed's outlook from last fall, when it cut rates three times in response to the global financial crisis. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: The Assembly Insurance Committee heard testimony yesterday on a bill that would impose a surcharge on health maintenance organizations to pay more than $140 million in doctor and hospital bills left over from the recent collapse of two H.M.O.'s. The bill would create a consumer protection association that would assess H.M.O.'s a percentage of their premiums to pay bills left unpaid by the failure of HIP Health Plan of New Jersey and American Preferred Provider Plan, said Steve Wilson, a spokesman for the Assembly Majority Office. The bill covers only unpaid medical bills, not claims by creditors.

headline.main: Panel Hears Testimony On H.M.O. Fee Bill
